This scarecrow is the only thing in the field that looks as if it may have been tended to recently, its dark suit unfaded and neat. At the base of the scarecrow’s cross, ants scurry up and the wooden pole, teeming over each other

The year is 1862, the second year of the American civil w The bank, a large, plain building, rests in the center of small southern town, on the side of a wide dirt road. A g of six Confederate soldiers, in gray uniforms, ride down street on well-groomed horses, towards the bank.

Four of the six soldiers enter the bank, the middle two e carrying two bags. The bank’s counter has two barred wind one of which is already occupied by an attractive young w in an expensive dress, who is speaking intently with the teller, a young, awkward man. The four soldiers cross to other window. The old male teller at this window looks at the soldiers surprised, as two of them set their bags heavily on the counter.
Your manager in? The elderly teller nods. TALL SOLDIER (CONT’D) Go get him. (CONTINUED)

The soldiers wait, looking around the bank, as the teller hurries away behind the window. Aside from themselves and woman at the other window, there are no other customers i the bank. A rough-looking man stands next to the door, a large four-chamber revolver stuck prominently into his be obviously representing security. A door in the wall rattles and a middle-aged man steps ou wearing spectacles. He moves towards the soldiers solicitously, the old teller following him. The tall sold looks at the man levelly. TALL SOLDIER (CONT’D) You MacCready?
Yes, I am. Fred MacCready’s my name. How may I help you gentlemen?
Corporal Williams said you might have a place where we could put this. He indicates the bags.
(hesitates) Did the corporal give you any message for me? The tall soldier takes a folded piece of paper from his pocket and hands it to MacCready. MacCready unfolds the p and nervously looks at it.

The two other Confederate soldiers are standing outside t bank, looking around, while one of them feeds the horses. other soldier, blonde and covered with dust, standing a f feet away, looks down the dirt street. A few hundred feet away, four more Confederate soldiers a riding horses towards them, moving slowly. A black man le one of their horses, walking on foot. A medium-sized dog trots alongside him. The blonde soldier, seeing this, turns to his companion.
Hey, look at that. The other soldier looks up from his task, squinting, revealing bad teeth. (CONTINUED)
Who the hell are they?
I don’t know. The blonde soldier turns and faces the oncoming gray soldiers, waving.
MacCready faces the four soldiers inside the bank, cheerf pocketing the note.
Well, it looks like everything’s in order, then. You understand my having to check. Security these days. The tall soldier looks at him, unsmiling.
You got a safe we should be taking this to?
The best in the state... But first, I’1l need you to sign for this.
Why?
(faltering) Well... I mean, you will want a receipt for it, won’t you?
Oh. Yeah, sure. MacCready looks at the elderly teller, gesturing towards counter. The teller shuffles away.

The four soldiers on horseback approach the two soldiers outside the bank. The man in front, with his horse being by the black man, has dark hair and eyes and is chewing tobacco. This is WILLIAM. The black man, TODD, is slender, and watches the two soldiers, unblinking. The blonde soldier addresses Willia somewhat hesitantly. (CONTINUED)

Where you men in from? William slides off his horse, landing on his feet, and ti the horse’s reins to a wooden post in front of the bank. three men on horseback behind him do the same. One of these men is SAM, who looks like a younger version William and is also chewing tobacco. The other two are JOSEPH, a large, wide-shouldered man, and CLYDE, a smalle wiry, rugged man. The four move towards the two soldiers friendly.
Camp just over that way, about two miles east, near the swamps.
(somewhat suspiciously) Who’s your lieutenant over there?
Ain’t got no lieutenant right now. Cap’ain Louison’s around, though. The two soldiers relax slightly at this response. William taps Todd on the shoulder, roughly.
Go help the men with their horses, boy. Todd shoots him a quick look, then walks over to the two soldiers’ horses, head bowed. The bucktooth soldier hands the feed bag.
What’re you doing here in town?
(gestures) Got some business at the bank.
Well, you’re gonna have to wait a few minutes. William squints up at the sun.
Nope. Can’t wait. William begins moving towards the bank. Sam, Joseph and C follow. (CONTINUED)

(steps forward, nervous) No, I mean, you really gotta. We can’t let anyone in there right now. It’ll just be a few minutes, though. The four men do not pause, continuing towards the door to bank. The blonde soldier and the bucktooth soldier exchan quick glances, then the blonde soldier draws his rifle, cocking the hammer and leveling it at the William.

Now, stop right- He is cut off as the blade of a thick knife enters his ne Todd spins, tugging the knife out of the blonde soldier’s throat, releasing a spout of blood, and stabs the bucktoo soldier in the chest before the bucktooth soldier can rea Todd looks up at William, stooping over the body of the bucktooth soldier. William nods, and Todd leans over and picks up the blonde soldier’s rifle, then begins untying horses. William opens the doors to the bank.

MacCready and one of the other soldiers are carrying the bags behind the counter when William and his men burst in the bank, drawing guns. Joseph grabs the security guard as the man reaches for hi revolver. They struggle for a moment, then Joseph breaks guard’s neck, dropping him to the floor, and pulls out a William aims his pistols at the men with the bags.

Hold it there. MacCready and the soldiers freeze. The tall soldier pulls rifle from a holster at his bag, swinging it towards Will Sam leans over, aiming his pistol, and shoots the tall soldier in the head. William empties his guns, hitting both MacCready and the other soldier, as Clyde and Joseph shoot the other two soldiers. The elderly teller, the young teller and the girl are sti standing, staring. Slowly, the younger teller reaches und the counter. The girl, standing across from him, sees thi She flips a straight razor out of her sleeve, leans forwa and cuts the teller’s throat. The young teller falls back spraying the girl with blood. (CONTINUED)

The soldier who was moving the bags with MacCready is twitching on the ground, gasping, still alive. William an Clyde both notice this. Clyde begins pouring gun powder f a paper packet into the barrel of his pistol, but William sighs, steps forward, and takes out a hunting knife. He w over to the soldier and stabs him in the chest William stands up, surveying the room. His eyes meet the girl’s and he smiles.

Hey, there. William moves over to the girl, ANNABELLE, and they kiss. wipes her razor clean on her dress, then tucks it back in her sleeve. The young teller lies still on the opposite s of the counter.
Quick work, Annabelle. You cut him? I didn’t even see it.
Alright, anyone else still alive in here? Clyde gestures at the elderly teller, who is backed away them in a corner, trembling and pale.
Him, sort of. William begins loading one of his pistols.
Well, kill him. Clyde aims his pistol at the elderly teller.

No, please don’t... The teller chokes, then clutches at his chest. His eyes r up into his head and he falls to his knees, then to the floor, his eyes closing. The teller lies still on the flo Clyde looks at William, frowning, then turns back towards elderly teller’s prone body and shoots him.
Just in case. Joseph and Sam are holding the four bags. (CONTINUED)
Those heavy, Joseph? Joseph nods, excited.
Well then, let’s get the hell out of here.

Todd is standing in front of the bank with his gun drawn, other hand holding all six of the soldiers’ horses by the reins. He warily looks up and down the street. The dog st next to Todd, indifferent People are watching Todd, and the bank, but nobody is doi anything. Most people have run into buildings to hide, bu the rest are watching Todd, unnaturally. He returns their gaze, looking from face to face. William, Annabelle, Clyde, Joseph and Sam come running ou the bank. Todd turns to them, lifting the dog up into a saddlebag on one of the horses.

About fucking time. They each leap up onto a horse, grabbing the reins and ta their horses off down the street at a gallop. Ahead of th three men in Confederate uniforms run out of a grocery st aiming rifles.

Oh, hell. Clyde, William and Todd begin shooting at the soldiers as they ride past. One of the soldiers is hit, falling back Behind him, a woman screams. Next to her, a very small bo lying on the ground, blood all over his face and neck. Everything grows still for a moment as William sees this. William flinches and looks away from the boy as the six thunder past the grocery store. Then they are down the st and gone, as the two remaining soldiers run around the st corner, after their horses. The woman kneels over the sma boy in the street, weeping.
The six ride their horses quickly, Sam next to William. T dog is riding in Sam’s saddlebag, and Sam feeds it a piec dried beef. (CONTINUED)
Good boy, Dog. (to William) How many do you think’1l be after us?
Not many, right away, and those’d be the only that could catch up in time to find us. William looks over at Sam, who has a dark circle of blood growing on his shoulder, over a hole in the shirt.
You’re hit. Sam looks where William is looking, down at his own shoul

Just in the shoulder. I don’t think it’s real bad, I can move it around okay, it ain’t near the bone or nothing. We’1ll get it out later. William looks like he wants to say more, but turns away a urges his horse on faster.

The six carefully work their way through a dim, wooded ar carefully guiding their horses through trees. Sam’s shirt sleeve is red with blood, but the bleeding seems to have stopped and Sam is greedily eating an apple. Annabelle and William ride near the front, conversing quietly. Annabelle is holding a compass, watching the nee sway. Todd moves his horse up next to them.
We lost?

No. We got a couple more miles of this though, then we’ll reach a small stream, should be easy to cross. Then we stay on a road through a few fields and we should be at the place we’re staying by nightfall. After that, day and a half’s ride to Mexico. Todd is silent for a moment. (CONTINUED)
Annabelle
Who runs this place we’re staying at tonight?
No one.
No one?

When I was staying at the Union hospital up near Chatsville, getting some metal bits pulled out of my arm by the most beautiful nurse in the world... (he looks at Annabelle, who ignores him) ...I was put next to this soldier, just a kid, really, had a gut wound somebody put there with a bayonet. We talked all the day, got to know each other pretty good, he was a right enough sort. Around the end, when he was starting to get pretty sick all the time... looks up at them.
The bile in his guts spread.

Yeah. That it did. Kid told me about this place he inherited down south, big ‘ol house, couple hundred acres, he got it from some great-uncle he never knew. He gave me pretty good directions to the place, he didn’t have no family or a girl or nothing, and said he wanted me to join up with him if he ever made it down there. Kid planned to get rich off farming. He wasn’t too bright. (shrugs) He died a couple of days after that.
(almost to herself) His name was Jeffy. Jeffy Hollister. He was a good kid. He used to call me ‘Belle.
Yeah, I remember that. (pause) (MORE) (CONTINUED)
So, anyway, I guess you could say the place we’re headed to is mine. Or anyone’s who wants it, anyway.
What if some folks moved in there?

It’s in the middle of nowhere... I figure if we drop the name Jeffy Hollister whoever’s living there might show some hospitality. If they don’t, well, we’1l have to take care of them either way. It’s a place to stay. They ride in silence for a moment. The forest, overcast w trees, is growing darker.
How’s your brother doing? William glances over at Sam.

He’s fine for now. We’1ll get the bullet out when we reach the house, Annabelle can take care of that. After that, he should be good. The group is silent as they continue through the trees. Something moves in a thick bush as they move past, and Jo jumps, startled. A bird’s harsh, unidentifiable cry comes from the bush. Clyde laughs at Joseph.
Whoa, Joseph, stay on your horse there, big guy. Just a crow or something.
(embarrassed) You better shut up. Clyde smiles, but is silent.

The sun is setting as the six make their way down a narro dirt road, corn fields on either side of them. The rows o corn cast the field in shadow, so that the road ahead is dark. At the front of the group, William and Annabelle speak quietly. (CONTINUED)
Annabelle 11.
I think I killed a kid. Back in the town. Did you see it?
Yeah, I thought I saw him fall. You sure that was you? Could’ve been anyone.
I think it was me.
Why?
I don’t know. (pause) Don’t tell the others. If they didn’t notice, they shouldn’t know. is silent for a moment, thinking.
We almost there? William nods. Up ahead, ANNABELLE (CONT’D) We’re not lost, are we? I haven’t seen a house for awhile.
They’re back there. It’s along this road, we just gotta go until we find it.
It’s getting dark soon. Too many clouds for the moon to do us any good.
I know it. a clanking sound comes. The six immediately slow their horses, moving quietly. William’s
(speaking softly to Todd) What’s that?
I don’t know. You got a lantern? eyes are narrowed and cold. (CONTINUED)

Don’t. Hold up a bit. The six ride forward in the dark, very slowly, reaching t top of a small hill. The noises from ahead are now more regular, and the sound of a horse’s footfall can be distinguished from a regular creaking sound. Further along the path, in the darkness ahead, a dim ligh becomes visible. The light sways back and forth slightly, moving towards them. The dog, Dog, looks up and growls slightly. Sam puts a hand on Dog to silence him.
(whispering) You see that? Annabelle draws out her pistol.
Yeah. The group has grown silent, watching the bobbing light mo closer.
Will-o’-wisps.
We ain’t near no swamp.
Ain’t unheard of.
It looks like a lantern.
Sam?
Yeah?
Give us some light here.
You sure?
Come on. (CONTINUED)

Sam strikes a match on his thumbnail and holds it to a so caked lantern, lighting the wick. The lantern fizzles, th glows brightly, illuminating a large, black horse several yards in front of the group. They all jump.

Shit! The horse continues walking passively towards them. As it moves closer, the carriage that the horse is pulling beco visible. A lantern and several pots, pans and other unidentifiable objects hang from the roof of the carriage old man sits at the front, behind the horse, silent. William clears his throat and addresses the old man:

Excuse me. The man does not respond. Joseph stirs on his horse, uneasily. William speaks louder. WILLIAM (CONT’D) Excuse me! The old man draws back on the horse’s reins. The horse gr softly and comes to a stop. The old man turns to face William, his eyes looking beyond him. The old man has no pupils; his eyes are pale blue, washed clean by glaucoma.
Who’s that?
I, uh... Say, we’re looking for the Hollister place. Is it far from here?
Hollister? (shakes his head) Never heard of it. The old man turns away, lifting the horse’s reins.
(surprised) Are you sure? It’s a large farm, should be just up the road. Right after a creek.
There’s no creek around here. Not for miles. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

(pause) Sorry I couldn’t help you. The old man lashes the reins and the horse starts forward again, easily pulling the carriage into motion. William a his group sit silently, pensive. As the carriage moves past them, Sam’s lantern reveals a standing inside the carriage, looking out at them through oblong window cut into the side of the carriage. The boy appears to be mentally disabled, and watches them complet without movement or expression. After a moment, the carriage is past the group, its lante light fading into the darkness of the road behind them. Todd spits tobacco juice into the cornfield as Joseph cou uneasily. Annabelle and Sam look at William, who kicks at side of his horse.
Well, come on, then. Annabelle and Sam immediately follow him. Todd, Joseph an Clyde exchange glances, then head after William, one by o

The road is getting narrower and increasingly covered wit tall grass, bent down in some areas but seemingly untouch in others. Annabelle and William can barely ride alongsid each other. Sam is riding in front of them, slowly, with running alongside Sam’s horse, visible in the lantern’s circle of light.
I don’t like the looks of this.
We’ve slept on grass before.
We don’t even know where we are.

We’ve got our compasses. (he nods over to his left) Mexico’s that way. Up ahead, Sam’s horse suddenly comes to a dead stop. Will and Annabelle tug on their horses’ reins quickly to avoid running into him, causing their horses to rear up slightl (CONTINUED)
Hey!
(tense) What is it?

Well, look at this. Sam lifts up his lantern in front of him as the others cr around him, taking their horses into the field, which is suddenly thin and rocky. A creek, about fifteen feet wide bubbles in front of them, its waters black by the lantern light.
Well, what the hell.

(to Dog) C’mere, girl. Sam lifts Dog up into his saddlebag, then rides out into creek. The water, though moving at a good speed, is only about a foot and a half deep. William nudges his horse forward, into the water, looking down.
Shit. Crazy old man. William begins riding forward, across the creek.
Come on! It shouldn’t be far from here. The rest of the group follow him forward, along the trail

The trail forks up ahead. Perhaps there was a path to the house once, but if so, the path was long ago consumed by thick corn fields that surround the house on all sides. I front of the house, the yard is so crowded with tall gras and weeds that it appears to be a field itself. The house sits on the horizon, just visible by the final orange rays of the sun. There is a stone well to the side the house, and clotheslines hang at angles just beyond th well. Behind the house is a tall barn, almost as big as t house itself. (CONTINUED)

William, Annabelle and Sam are the first to see the house and they stand in the road, waiting for the other three t catch up. The house, a dark silhouette by the sun setting behind it, presents something of an ominous sight. Willia wets his lips with his tongue.

Well. Looks like a nice place. Sam climbs off his horse, holding its reins. The horse sh away, and Sam pets it, hushing it. Annabelle and William climb off their horses. Annabelle watches the house carefully. In one of the wind of the house, a previously indistinguishable shape sudden shifts and disappears from the window. Annabelle, seeing this, involuntarily takes a step back.
What is it?
(considers) I saw something in one of the windows.
I’m sure there was something in one of the windows. That whole place has got to be filled with all kinds of critters. Probably saw a bird or something.
(to Annabelle) Something, or someone?
Someone. Like they was watching us. William looks at the house, as Clyde, Todd and Joseph rid behind them.

We'll be careful. William steps out into the cornfield, pushing the stalks apart with one hand, holding his horse’s reins with the other. Suddenly, a creature with glowing eyes leaps out at Willi from the field, squealing. The creature is about the size a large raccoon. William shouts and spins to the side as creature runs past him. (CONTINUED)
Just as it passes William, the creature is knocked onto i back by a gunshot. Sam holds a smoking gun, frowning down the creature. Dog begins growling.
Jesus Christ...

What the hell is that? The creature has soft white fur on its stomach, but has a like snout, long claws, and a bald, pink tail. The hair o its back is thick and bristled. The creature shakes for a moment, bleeding from its back, its legs pivoting, then i still. Dog quiets down.
It looks like some kind of giant rat.
Yeah, right. Did you see its eyes?

How do you think I knew where to shoot at? Annabelle softly walks over to the creature and kicks its side, barely. The creature is still. SAM (CONT’D) (to William) You all right? William stiffens slightly, regaining his composure.
Yeah. I’m fine. That thing gave me a start, that’s all.
It ain’t breathing.
Well, that’s good news. What is it?
Kinda looks like a porcupine. Or a pig.
Built almost like a baby bear, a little. (CONTINUED)
Maybe a porcupine and a muskrat had a kid. Clyde looks at Joseph quickly, to see if he is kidding.
Yeah, maybe.

Well, let’s get going. William steps back towards the cornfield. Everyone looks him, hesitantly. Williams moves towards the cornfield, th when no one follows, turns back sardonically towards the group. WILLIAM (CONT’D) Hey, Sam?
Yeah?
Keep your eyes out for more of those things, alright? William turns and walks into the cornfield. Sam follows, Todd, then Annabelle and the rest, leading their horses.

The six work their way through the dark cornfield, pushin unruly stalks to the side. Sam, Joseph and Todd each hold lanterns, which do little good in the dense cornfield exc to create alarming shadows. The horses make nervous sound every now and then, but continue forward. Suddenly Annabelle, up ahead, gives a sharp cry. Joseph, and Clyde rush forward towards the sound of her voice. Annabelle is standing, one hand on her chest, in front of scarecrow. The scarecrow’s limbs are tied to a wooden cro with barbed wire. A canvas sack, filled with peculiar lum and shadows, forms the scarecrow’s head. Joseph looks up it.
(annoyed) Oh, what the hell... (CONTINUED)
That thing scared the life out of me. I thought it was a man.
It’s creepy, alright. Todd and Clyde stare up at the scarecrow skeptically. Dog stands next to him. Joseph sniffs the air.
What smells funny?
(to Annabelle) You want us to take it down?
No! Don’t touch it! I mean, there’s no point. Let’s not bother. It just gave me a start, that’s all.
All right. William coughs and spits.

(sarcastic) Yes, it’s a very frightening scarecrow. If I were a crow, I’d go elsewhere. Since I’m not, anyone else want to get a move on? Annabelle looks down, embarrassed. William rolls his eyes her and the group moves past the scarecrow. Dog and Josep give it a wide berth and the horses make nervous noises a they pass.
What direction is the house in? Hey, Joseph, can you see the house?
Not over this corn. Want me to climb up on my horse?
William, you know what direction we’re headed in? William looks back at him, then points ahead, to the left (CONTINUED)
The house is that way.
You sure? I would’ve thought we’d be there by now.
Cornfields always look smaller before you’re fighting your way through them.
I guess that’s about right. They work their way through the field. One of the horses whinnies. SAM (CONT’D) Damn, it’s quiet.

I know. Clyde is in the lead, gruffly shoving his way through the cornstalks. He suddenly stumbles out of the cornfield and finds himself facing the house. The house is worn, its boards bleached by exposure to the elements. The windows are dark. The front door leans open
Well, hell. The others stumble up behind Clyde.
Well, there it is.
Yeah. William looks around. Nobody is moving.

Come on, then. William walks over to a twisted oak tree, leaning several feet in front of the house, and ties his horse to a hangi branch. William’s horse shuffles slightly, rolling its ey William consoles it. (CONTINUED)
Shhh, girl. We’1l get you some water ina bit.
The horses are acting weird.
Of course they are. They’re horses. They’re stupid and crazy.
Huh. Well, someone should rub them down later, if they’re gonna be any good tomorrow.

I’1l1 do it, I don’t mind. The rest of the group tie their horses to the tree. Willi moves over, towards the house; the others follow. Sam tak step forward, then quickly steps back, looking at the gro
Hell...
What?

I just stepped on a bird. A dead, slightly decayed bird rests on the ground. Sam examines the sole of his boot. SAM (CONT’D) That’s a first. Sam looks around. Another dead bird rests on the ground, few feet away. Dog sniffs at it. SAM (CONT’D) Look, there’s another one! Annabelle is clearly not very interested in this.
Huh.
There must be, like, cats around here or something. (CONTINUED)
Yeah. Come on. I want to get that bullet out of you before an infection can start spreading.
Sure thing. (to Dog) Come on, Dog! Sam follows Annabelle up towards the house. Dog, after a moment, trots after him.

William steps up onto the wooden porch. As Joseph steps u next to him, the boards beneath them creak ominously. Jos and William look at each other, then William takes Joseph lantern and steps into the house. Todd looks back at the horses, tied to the oak tree. The horses are silent. Todd moves up onto the porch.

William’s lantern illuminates the front room of the house wooden table sits over in a corner of the room, surrounde several chairs. A thick layer of dust covers nearly everything. Joseph begins to step forward into the room, but William a hand across Joseph’s chest, stopping him. Joseph looks William, questioningly. William points the lantern down at the floor. Two pairs o footprints are imprinted in the dust on the wooden floor, large boot prints. The boot prints lead off into the dark of the house. Clyde and Todd have moved in behind William and Joseph.
What’s going on? Clyde sees the footprints on the floor and is quiet.
It’s probably just some tramps. I’d settle here, if I was them. Let’s look around and find ‘em. William looks at Todd. (CONTINUED)
TODD (CONT’D) There’s only two of them.

(nods) Alright. But everyone be careful. They move into the house, followed by Sam and Annabelle. trots in with them, looking around. Dog’s ears are up. Joseph immediately crosses over to the wooden table and d the four bags. The table creaks. One of the bags comes op slightly, and a few gold coins spill out onto the table. Joseph looks at the gold, then picks a coin up and bites He examines his tooth marks in the gold.
Don’t chew on the gold, Joseph. Joseph quickly puts the coin back down on the table. Will addresses the group:
Let’s split up into pairs, search this floor and the upstairs. And the cellar, if this place has one.
They might be out in that old barn. That looked big enough.

We’1l check that after we finish with the house. William steps further into the house, shining his lantern around. A kitchen area, with a coal stove, is barely visi through a doorway; the corners of the kitchen are dark.
I want to get to work on Sam’s shoulder right away.
Yeah. That’s a good idea.
It’s fine. It can wait.
Oh yeah, little brother? Bullets just bounce off you now, huh? (CONTINUED)
Sam grins at William.
Clyde and Joseph, you guys take the upstairs. Todd and I will check this floor. Clyde and Joseph nod and walk off. William looks over at who is staring around the room.
Hey, you want to come with us? Sniff something out? Dog looks at William, then slinks under a chair and curls
That’s thing’s goddamn useless, Sam. Alright, then. William and Todd begin moving away.
(to William) Be careful.
You too. Sam, keep a hand on your gun. I don’t want anybody sneaking up on us tramps or no.
Don’t worry about that.
I’m sure they’ve seen our lanterns by now, so they might come looking for us.
Maybe we scared them off.

If they’ve been staying here? Not likely. William and Todd walk into the kitchen. Annabelle sets he lantern down on the table, turning it up, so that the roo grows brighter. She beckons Sam over to a chair; he sits. Annabelle begins fiddling through a satchel, pulling out tools, as Sam unbuttons and peels off his shirt. He wince his shoulder stretches. (CONTINUED)

Leave it on, we’ll just move it aside. Annabelle pushes Sam’s shirt open, over his shoulders, exposing his torso. The bullet wound in Sam’s shoulder is very dark, almost black, and moist with purple blood. A large, bluish welt surrounds the wound. Annabelle winces she sees the wound. ANNABELLE (CONT’D) Jesus. Annabelle gently presses on the swollen area of flesh tha surrounds the bullet hole. Dark blood, almost black, well out of the scabby wound and crawls down Sam’s chest. Sam, curious, peers down, trying to see his own shoulder
Yeah, that doesn’t look too good, does it?
William and Todd look around the kitchen. Todd opens the stove and sifts the ashes inside.
This hasn’t been used anytime soon.
Huh. William is looking at the counter, where a dirty, cloth d lies, its limbs askew. One of the doll’s button eyes is missing.
Let’s keep moving.
Yeah.
Clyde and Joseph cautiously make their way up the stairs Joseph in the lead.
This is a pretty nice place. Real fancy. Guy who built it must have been rich. (CONTINUED)
They reach the top of the stairwell and find themselves i short hallway, with three doors, one in front of them, th other two at opposite ends of the hallway.
Think those guys are up here?
Maybe. Don’t worry, they’1l take one look at you and wet themselves, big guy.
I could crush them.
I know it. Here, you go check that room down there, and I’1l check this one.

Okay. INT. CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - EVENING Joseph moves down the hallway, away from Clyde. Joseph op the door at the end of the hall and walks slowly into the room. Joseph looks around the sparse bedroom. Two small beds re against one wall. There is a dresser in the room, and a closet. Joseph carefully walks into the room, checking behind the beds. Nothing is there. He moves over to the closet door, somewhat nervous. Joseph turns the doorknob slowly and opens the closet doo shining his lantern in.
